comments.commentBody: The NBA and NHL use the regular season records of the finalists to determine which team gets to play four games at home.  Why is baseball, instead, using the All-Star game to make this determination?

The ref was bad. Period. I don't know what else there is to discuss in this. Nobody seems to question that De Jong should have been hauled off to jail after 28 minutes. Had the ref done his job at that point, I don't think there's much doubt that a 10 man Dutch team could have survived 60 minutes of relentless Spanish control. And had they turned even nastier (would that have been possible?), then a 9 man Dutch team probably would have been looking at a 7 or 8 to nothing score by the end of the match. And everyone would have _enjoyed_ the spectacle (except the Dutch fans), as no doubt Spain would have made a delightful exhibition of it. But the Dutch (soccer) fans weren't going to enjoy the match no matter what happened--either getting slaughtered by the Spanish with few players on the field, or seeing what actually happened (thugs and criminals running the show).

Everyone seems to agree "the best team won". So the only other thing you can really say about all this is that the ref made the wrong choice by attempting to keep it "equal" by not sending off the Dutch. That just led to a really ugly match, and had the Dutch won it, it would have sent the wrong signal to the entire world--cheating pays.
Nice debut, Michael.... Fascinating that you want each of your puzzles to be a pangram!

Senator Romero is ignorant and misinformed. Serpentine is perfectly stable unless it is broken up and the fibers are inhaled. Too bad there aren't more geologists in office, this country might be in better shape if they were.

Let's not forget that granite is radioactive, and thus should be outlawed. And lava is lethal at one point or another. And oxygen causes fire. And the sun is carcinogenic, and could blind anybody. Also California may cause death from earthquakes and potholes.
PA

Unfortunately, State Senator Romero appears to have strayed, just a tad, into the bereft miasma of political correctness. This "throwing the baby out with the bath water" approach can only be described as an intellectual faux pas. It condones the dumbing-down of her constituents while further embarrassing this state.
Leave the rock alone.  Serpentine's pretty.  Don't eat rocks - duh!
Gee, and maybe the American Eagle eats spotted owls!
What do you expect from the state that has Proposition 65 signs on every beach warning that the beach contains silica (ie sand)?
There are no bad rocks, only rocks used badly.

This really disgusts me, not just because of what these politicians OUGHT to be doing with their time. What a bunch of no nothing knee-jerks!

Serpentine is beautiful, it has amazing characteristics, and it is the basis of a certain kind of plant (etc) habitat. I'd go as far to say that it is a thrilling rock, if you care about such things, which I do.
CA serpentine outcrops also host a huge number of unique plant species that are adapted to the unusual chemistry of the rock.
We should all defrock our state sacred cows, and then let veterinarians sort it out.
How comically uninteresting!

Folks -

Unless it is friable, meaning it is capable of airborne disbursement, it is inert.

Meaning, harmless.

I know of which I speak. Former plaintiff's asbestos attorney in Philadelphia.

No agenda, here.

You could put these pebbles in your morning cereal and eat them without consequence.

Just don't grind them and spread upon your salad, or anywhere else.

: - )
There's NEVER a shortage of nuts in California!!

In answer to Marie in New York ( Comment 17 ),

In a word, NO! You can't find a hardware store here without a sign in the window saying something to the effect that "Things in this store have been found by the State of California to cause birth defects, cancer, and/or enough insanity to live in California in the first place!!!" You have to laugh at these idiots here or they'll drive you stark raving nuts!!! :-)

Kurt
The problem is that the rock doesn't have union approval and won't provide $100,000 pensions and benefits for life!

So California's democratic legislators are now protecting people from the cancerous ravages a naturally occurring, attractive  mineral? This is do-goodism taken to its highest level. Rejoice! Next we remove the bear from the state flag to acknowledge the thousands of innocents who have died or been mauled over the years. With serpentine and the grizzly emblem removed from public exposure, we can venture outdoors with Chicken Little again and frolic. Wait , that little red star on the flag scares me too-- kind of like a meteorite or something. It might fall off and hurt someone. Get rid of it too!

It's worth mentioning that the study of California serpentine at UC Davis played an important role in the formation of the modern theory of tectonics (which qualifies it as a cool rock in my book anyway).
Aaarrgghh...can't we all just get a realistic budget passed?

Serpentine is an ocean-bed rock, and is found in California where the Pacific tectonic plate has attached to the North American plate and been elevated above sea level.  Perhaps, following required legislature on carcinogenic chemicals California should ban all landmasses west of the San Andreas fault as containing compounds known to cause cancer in California. That will keep our government busy for a while...

Another of our finest with too much time and too many rocks in her head. Gloria has has wasted all this time on a rock instead of putting forth any effort on the California budget which lingers uncompleted and at least $20 billion in the hole.

I guess this is the best legislature money can buy, here in California!

JPG recommends not yelling across the airways. Our frustration as geologists in this matter derives from the fact that neither the supporters or our state legislators would engage on this issue. Trying to educate the public through blogging and twittering seems to have been the only way to get our message through. Serpentine is a rock with a fascinating geologic story, many minerals that are valuable, and it forms soils that support many of California's endemic plants. The best way to teach about asbestos and the threat it poses is to KEEP the rock so that students in coming decades can learn about both the positive and negative aspects (and geologists see a lot of positives).
What bothers me is that an elected official could fall for such facile rubbish.
